instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG? PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG Is a single phase of CPU VCORE for the graphics processor integrated into the CPU before it is combined into one PPVCORE_S0_AXG rail.
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD – once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Hi team,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had a liquid damage but cleanned by someone else.
the board is turning ON, fan spin and getting faster and faster , maybe sense issue.

I have <SIGNAL>PVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> :1.159V and no <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL>:

at <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>:<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUAXG</SIGNAL>: 8.37V

at <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>P5V_S0_CPUIMVP_VDD</SIGNAL>: 5.065V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>: 3.319V

<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_BOOT1G</SIGNAL>: 4.791V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_UGATE1G</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE1G</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_LGATE1G</SIGNAL>:0V

Resistance pin8/9: 56Ohms OK
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_IMAXB</SIGNAL>: 1.953V
<RESISTOR>R7440</RESISTOR>: 10 Ohms
<RESISTOR>R7423</RESISTOR>: 10 Ohms

by comparaison
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_IMAXA</SIGNAL>: 6.229V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_IMAXA</SIGNAL>: 1.844V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE1</SIGNAL>: 1.166V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_LGATE1</SIGNAL>: 4.355V
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_IMAXA</SIGNAL> is 1.965V


<RESISTOR>R7467</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7469</RESISTOR> both removed and mesured around 80Kohms
Resistance to gnd at L7550/<RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR> 15 Ohms

Question: What is not present or peventing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> for not turning the AXG rail ON?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: What is the problem the board turning on or the sensors failing?? Run ASD and report any errors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Hi , thanks for replying 
​​​​​​
I've forgotten to say that it doesn't chime, doesn't boot, doesn't display , and also no backlight..
It's just fan spinning faster and faster.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I think <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> is present only when screen turns on / is detected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: So i've replaced the Lio board and also tested with a good known screen but it's still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I know from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, for Sandy Bridge AXG CORE should be present from the begining; it appears with 0.9V but rapidly drop and stays at 0.45V.
Maybe not valid for al of them.

In case of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, with Ivy Bridge I saw many of them giving image on LCD without AXG VCORE.
You may see it for 2-3s with 1V and drops to 0V.

So I cannot confirm 100% for your board; supposed to be Sandy Bridge.
But if you can confirm USB activity, then probably AXG CORE stays at 0V until graphics load increases, like in Ivy Bridge models...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Hi Team,


I replaced the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> with a SOIC package one, because no WSON is stock, with a fresh clean dump: Turned it ON but had the same result, then I press power button before plugging the charger suddenly it chimed and booted correctly with image and backlight.

But I've noticed that the ON/OFF power button doesn't work: I can't turn it OFF whith long press on the Power button.
I did a PRAM reset successfully, but not sure for the SMC reset as the Power button doesn't react: so far Power button doesn't work.

Should I open a new topic for this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Disconnect keyboard.
Use <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> to see if turns on/off correctly...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Hi,
You can mark this thread as SOLVED, 
Regarding the Power buton the pin 11 of J5700 was not soldered correctly, after soldering it was still NOK i followed the line to different points on the trackpad board, passed throught a 1 KOhms resistor to the keyboard connector on the ttrackpad board when pressing on the power button I had no feedboack to the ground directly at that point so I assume that it's a keyboard issue.

Thanks 2Informaticos for your help and support Muchas Gracias amigo
